docblock.description: This is the PSR-3 Logger Class. It allows for any number of appenders and comes with a Null, Console, and SPlunkStorm appender built in.
docblock.long-description: It simply delegates all log-level-specific methods to the `log` method to reduce boilerplate code that a simple Logger that does the same thing with messages regardless of the error level has to implement.

docblock.description: The default log level for a new logger
Config for a default console Appender
Whether our log message should be prepended with a timestamp
Whether our log message should be prepended with a stanard message
A required message to prepend to log messages
Whether we have a required context
If we have a required context, this where we keep it.
The constructor, it takes an array of configuration information. And example of instantiating three appenders might look like:
docblock.long-description: ['logger' => ['level' => 'info'], 'appenders' => [ 'console' => [ 'target' => 'STDOUT', 'class' => 'Piton\Appender\Console' ], 'null' => ['class' => 'Piton\Appender\Null'], 'splunk' =>[ 'target' => 'api-fake.data.splunkstorm.com', 'class' => 'Piton\Appender\SplunkStorm', 'context' => [ 'SplunkStorm' => ['projectID'=>'SomeFakeProjectID', 'accessToken' => 'AnotherFakeAccessToken', 'apiVersion' => 1, 'apiEndpoint' => 'inputs/http', 'urlScheme' => 'https' ] ] ], ]

docblock.description: Configures our Logger with the configuration array.

docblock.long-description: Example: Entire website down, database unavailable, etc. This should trigger the SMS alerts and wake you up.
Example: Application component unavailable, unexpected exception.

docblock.description: Runtime errors that do not require immediate action but should typically be logged and monitored.
Exceptional occurrences that are not errors.
docblock.long-description: Example: Use of deprecated APIs, poor use of an API, undesirable things that are not necessarily wrong.
Example: User logs in, SQL logs.

docblock.description: Contains a list of instantiated levels.
Have we initialized the levelMap yet?
Whether we need to do the mappting or not
Find a level by either integer or string
Get one of the standard logging levels by name.
Returns true if this level has a higher or equal level than the level passed as argument, false otherwise.
Returns true if this level has a less or equal level than the level passed as argument, false otherwise.
Returns the string representation of this level.
Returns the string representation of this level.
Returns the integer representation of this level.
Our constructor, you can use common levels, or pass is some custom stuff!
Initializes the level map with the standard level constants defined in the class.
Checks the levelMap for the level, if it isn't there, we construct the level, then put it in there. Finally, return the level object.
